Thanks for letting us know about this issue.

This isn't a general Angular 2 file. The `es6-shim.js` is just a big glob of concatenated files that allow you run ES6 code in a current browser. It's just to get people up and running for the quickstart on the angular.io site.

All of this will change when TypeScript 1.5 releases with meta-data annotation support. Which I hope is soon!

. Thanks, @kahlil, but we're going to stick with `concurrently`.

Here's why (per one of our authors):

## 

We need functionality from `concurrently`. It's not just a matter or looking better.

It's the `--kill-others --success first` flags we added in PR #158 
`--kill-others` will terminate the other processes when the first finishes
`--success first` will give the status code of the first process to finish

These two together allow `concurrently \"http-server -s\" \"protractor protractor.config.js\" --kill-others --success first"` which means "run http-server and protractor at the same time, and once protractor is done kill off http-server"
. Added coincidentally as part of c18870fb02801c395bdba53e9d18cc7877c14fed
. It's super annoying, Rick. I've complains to Typescript team that they really need to let us choose the severity.

I am very open to an alternative suggestion
. In the latest version, we run `tsc` FIRST and then concurrently `tsc:w` and `lite`.

Yes, that runs `twice` each time you start. But it avoids the race condition in which the server starts before the first tsc finishes.

And if the first `tsc` fails, it aborts the entire task so the `concurrently ...` never happens. At least such has been my experience.

That was a problem!  `karma-test-shim` couldn't handle more than one base path containing spec files.

I've updated `karma-test-shim` and `karma.config`  accordingly.  I made your use case work with the following changes

```
// karma-test-shim
...
// builtPaths: root paths for output ("built") files
// get from karma.config.js, then prefix with '/base/' (default is 'app/')
var builtPaths = (__karma__.config.builtPaths || ['app/'])
                 .map(function(p) { return '/base/'+p;});
...
// Is a "built" file if is JavaScript file in one of the "built" folders
function isBuiltFile(path) {
  return isJsFile(path) &&
         builtPaths.reduce(function(keep, bp) {
           return keep || (path.substr(0, bp.length) === bp);
         }, false);
}
...
// karma.config.js
  var appBase    = 'app/';       // transpiled app JS and map files
  var appSrcBase = 'app/';       // app source TS files
  var appAssets  = 'base/app/'; // component assets fetched by Angular's compiler

  var testingBase    = 'spec/unit/'; // transpiled test JS and map files
  var testingSrcBase = 'spec/unit/'; // test source TS files
...

    client: {
      builtPaths: [appSrcBase, testingBase], // add more spec base paths as needed
      clearContext: false // leave Jasmine Spec Runner output visible in browser
    },
...
```

Last provider for a token wins.  You can keep adding providers — even for the same token — as long as you haven't _frozen_ the TestingModule by calling `compileComponents` or `createComponent`.
```ts
beforeEach( () => {
  TestBed.configureTestingModule({
    providers: [ { provide: URLLoaderSvc, useClass: Mock1 } ]
  });
});
...
beforeEach( () => {
  TestBed.configureTestingModule({
    providers: [ { provide: URLLoaderSvc, useClass: Mock2} ]
  });
});
...
beforeEach( () => {
  TestBed.configureTestingModule({
    providers: [ { provide: URLLoaderSvc, useClass: Mock3} ]
  });
});
...

Here's why (per one of our authors):

## 

We need functionality from `concurrently`. It's not just a matter or looking better.

It's the `--kill-others --success first` flags we added in PR #158 
`--kill-others` will terminate the other processes when the first finishes
`--success first` will give the status code of the first process to finish

These two together allow `concurrently \"http-server -s\" \"protractor protractor.config.js\" --kill-others --success first"` which means "run http-server and protractor at the same time, and once protractor is done kill off http-server"

. In the latest version, we run `tsc` FIRST and then concurrently `tsc:w` and `lite`.

Yes, that runs `twice` each time you start. But it avoids the race condition in which the server starts before the first tsc finishes.

And if the first `tsc` fails, it aborts the entire task so the `concurrently ...` never happens. At least such has been my experience.

That was a problem!  `karma-test-shim` couldn't handle more than one base path containing spec files.

I've updated `karma-test-shim` and `karma.config`  accordingly.  I made your use case work with the following changes

```
// karma-test-shim
...
// builtPaths: root paths for output ("built") files
// get from karma.config.js, then prefix with '/base/' (default is 'app/')
var builtPaths = (__karma__.config.builtPaths || ['app/'])
                 .map(function(p) { return '/base/'+p;});
...
// Is a "built" file if is JavaScript file in one of the "built" folders
function isBuiltFile(path) {
  return isJsFile(path) &&
         builtPaths.reduce(function(keep, bp) {
           return keep || (path.substr(0, bp.length) === bp);
         }, false);
}
...
// karma.config.js
  var appBase    = 'app/';       // transpiled app JS and map files
  var appSrcBase = 'app/';       // app source TS files
  var appAssets  = 'base/app/'; // component assets fetched by Angular's compiler

  var testingBase    = 'spec/unit/'; // transpiled test JS and map files
  var testingSrcBase = 'spec/unit/'; // test source TS files
...

    client: {
      builtPaths: [appSrcBase, testingBase], // add more spec base paths as needed
      clearContext: false // leave Jasmine Spec Runner output visible in browser
    },
...
```

FredLoney:
@wardbell this should be reopened. The error is an uncaught exception that occurs in several situations. For me, it occurs when a route is defined without a component declaration. The main issue is that the error message is useless and difficult to trace. In my case, it indirectly results from the resolve.ts code:

`_ => resolver.resolveComponent(<any>node.value.component).then(factory => {
          node.value._resolvedComponentFactory = factory;` 

which cascades as an error in a wholly different call stack. The assignment above should be guarded by checking for a `factory` value and issuing the appropriate error. In addition, the route should be validated beforehand. Furthermore, there should be a separate task to ensure that the (forthcoming?) route documentation specifically states what is required.

This issue and its response are symptomatic of a pervasive cavalier disregard for defensive programming in the Angular development process. I appreciate how developers under pressure let issues like this slide, but technical leads and QA should know better. Code review, anyone? Unfortunately, defensive programming must be integral to the development process and is difficult to address after initial  functional goals are achieved.

. @psnider I would avoid that solution, because afaik it will not work in the near future. Instead, what you should do is configure the testing module to import the `FormsModule`. 

```
TestBed.configureTestingModule({declarations: [AppComponent]});

. Well the testing module is like a normal module, right? So let's look at the toh-1 `app.module.ts`:

```
// #docregion
import { NgModule }      from '@angular/core';
import { BrowserModule } from '@angular/platform-browser';
import { FormsModule }   from '@angular/forms';

import { AppComponent }  from './app.component';

@NgModule({
  imports: [
    BrowserModule,
    FormsModule
  ],
  declarations: [
    AppComponent
  ],
  bootstrap: [ AppComponent ]
})
export class AppModule { }
```

Basically, `AppComponent` expects to be ran in an environment like this module. So I think what you're missing is to use the `imports` property:

```
 TestBed.configureTestingModule({
  imports: [FormsModule],
  declarations: [AppComponent]
});
```

Not too sure why the `BrowserModule` isn't needed though. I hope that'll be covered in the upcoming revision of the testing chapter that @wardbell is working on.

. While it is perfectly fine (and encouraged) to run the unit tests in watch mode while coding your app, running the e2e tests as well is overall a bad idea. The answer lies in what you said:

> When developing my application I'd like to have **immediate feedback**.

Unit tests are usually fast because they test the classes etc in isolation. So mostly it's just some bits of code running, albeit the tests might number in the hundreds.

E2E tests, however, are a different beast all together. They work by firing up the browser, interfacing with it via protractor, and running a bunch of interactions as if you were doing them yourself. Meaning it's clicking on buttons, sending keys to input fields, etc on chrome. This is way more computationally intensive, and overall slow, than unit tests.

So while 500 unit tests might take ten seconds, it's not that uncommon to have 100 e2e tests take 20 minutes.

Essentially this means that e2e tests can never give you the immediate feedback you want and need, while unit tests kinda can.

. Assuming you're using `typings` this is what you should do:
- delete `typings` folder (where all the installed typings are), `typings.json`
- in `package.json` delete `"postinstall": "typings install",` and `"typings": "typings",`
- do `npm install @types/{core-js,jasmine,node,protractor,selenium-webdriver} typescript@latest --save-dev`
- configure your editor to use the local Typescript 2.0 (for VSCode follow https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/typescript#_using-newer-typescript-versions)

Those should be all steps. https://github.com/angular/quickstart/pull/157 should update the quickstart to `@types/` sometime in the next months.

. @psnider I would avoid that solution, because afaik it will not work in the near future. Instead, what you should do is configure the testing module to import the `FormsModule`. 

```
TestBed.configureTestingModule({declarations: [AppComponent]});

. Well the testing module is like a normal module, right? So let's look at the toh-1 `app.module.ts`:

```
// #docregion
import { NgModule }      from '@angular/core';
import { BrowserModule } from '@angular/platform-browser';
import { FormsModule }   from '@angular/forms';

import { AppComponent }  from './app.component';

@NgModule({
  imports: [
    BrowserModule,
    FormsModule
  ],
  declarations: [
    AppComponent
  ],
  bootstrap: [ AppComponent ]
})
export class AppModule { }
```

Basically, `AppComponent` expects to be ran in an environment like this module. So I think what you're missing is to use the `imports` property:

```
 TestBed.configureTestingModule({
  imports: [FormsModule],
  declarations: [AppComponent]
});
```

Not too sure why the `BrowserModule` isn't needed though. I hope that'll be covered in the upcoming revision of the testing chapter that @wardbell is working on.

. While it is perfectly fine (and encouraged) to run the unit tests in watch mode while coding your app, running the e2e tests as well is overall a bad idea. The answer lies in what you said:

> When developing my application I'd like to have **immediate feedback**.

Unit tests are usually fast because they test the classes etc in isolation. So mostly it's just some bits of code running, albeit the tests might number in the hundreds.

E2E tests, however, are a different beast all together. They work by firing up the browser, interfacing with it via protractor, and running a bunch of interactions as if you were doing them yourself. Meaning it's clicking on buttons, sending keys to input fields, etc on chrome. This is way more computationally intensive, and overall slow, than unit tests.

So while 500 unit tests might take ten seconds, it's not that uncommon to have 100 e2e tests take 20 minutes.

Essentially this means that e2e tests can never give you the immediate feedback you want and need, while unit tests kinda can.

- do `npm install @types/{core-js,jasmine,node,protractor,selenium-webdriver} typescript@latest --save-dev`
- configure your editor to use the local Typescript 2.0 (for VSCode follow https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/typescript#_using-newer-typescript-versions)

Those should be all steps. https://github.com/angular/quickstart/pull/157 should update the quickstart to `@types/` sometime in the next months.

nalbion:
I experienced the same error.  The command seems to be doing what it needs to, so I instructed gulp_shell to ignore the error:

```
// strip off the sourceMaps.
gulp.task('build:strip_maps', shell.task(["sh strip_maps.sh"], {ignoreErrors:true}));
```

...that seemed to result in an empty `dist/es6-shim.js` file - not much use.

What did work, was to add `|| true` at the end of `strip_maps.sh`:

```
sed -e '/^\/\/\# source/d' -i '' dist/es6-shim.js || true
```
. I experienced the same error.  The command seems to be doing what it needs to, so I instructed gulp_shell to ignore the error:

gulp.task('build:strip_maps', shell.task(["sh strip_maps.sh"], {ignoreErrors:true}));
```

...that seemed to result in an empty `dist/es6-shim.js` file - not much use.

What did work, was to add `|| true` at the end of `strip_maps.sh`:

```
sed -e '/^\/\/\# source/d' -i '' dist/es6-shim.js || true
```
.

GunsAkimbo:
I got the same error if I hosted the app in IIS as an IIS application, which means the leading slashes points to the root of the server, not the application. To fix this, I removed the leading slashes:

```
System.paths = {
          'angular2/*':'angular2/*.js',
          'rtts_assert/*': 'rtts_assert/*.js',
          'services/*' : 'services/*.js',
          'todoApp': 'TodoApp.es6'
      };
```

And I got a 404 on the TodoApp.es6, I had to add a MIME-entry in IIS for the .es6 extension

```
"**/*.js": { "when": "$(basename).ts"},
"**/*.js.map": true
```

That in your settings.

On the other hand, this project is going to be deprecated in October.. When we started writing the docs, we had SystemJS and we created all our documentation around that. We had a "quickstart" guide that was the entry point of the rest of the docs. That was the time when Angular CLI didnt exist.

Nowadays, we don't have that quickstart guide anymore and all the documentation is being adapted for the Angular CLI.

When that  happens, this repository will be deprecated. It served its purpose when we started, but today, Angular CLI is a better option in everything.. This repository is now deprecated. The Angular Quickstart project was a nice starting point for creating Angular applications. bengy:
I also had the same issue (fs.inotify.max_user_watches was too low) but it works now. I think the problem is that lite-server watches all files, including node_modules, which totals in about 10600 files. This may be fixed by [this](https://github.com/johnpapa/lite-server/pull/57) pull request.
. I also had the same issue (fs.inotify.max_user_watches was too low) but it works now. I think the problem is that lite-server watches all files, including node_modules, which totals in about 10600 files. This may be fixed by [this](https://github.com/johnpapa/lite-server/pull/57) pull request.

SimonHurst:
For what it's worth the error message here sucks, It was actually an error in my code that created this in ability to build. Thankfully I was using a nice IDE that pointed it out to me or I could have spent hours on this.

Check your code that you've named your variables correctly I was missing an (s) on the end of mine, so obviously there was not object of that type available. Now if I'd made the error while the thing was running, I suspect I would have got a much nicer error message in the console. Probably just the way things have to be. But perhaps it could be improved? In the event you stoped it running and had to build it again. Only adding this here as this was pretty much at the top of the goole search and a nice pointer for whomever stumbles across this again.. wbeyda:
Had the same error I restarted the server and browser and it all of a sudden started working. 
. @iamkallolpratim , closed the browser tab. Stopped nodejs ctrl+c, then restarted nodejs  "npm start", and opened a new tab 127.0.0.1:3000. Browser opened with the " my first angular app" h1 or whatever it says. I went into main.ts and changed the message to "my second angular app" saved the file and went back to the browser. The browser was updated with "my second angular app" so I knew everything was working. Also make sure your nodejs package is sym linked correctly for Ubuntu. 

sudo ln -s /usr/bin/nodejs /usr/bin/node 

As far as I've read nodejs will always be broke on Ubuntu by default. I'd love to see it fixed by the next LTS release. But for now. It's what we have to do.

RickStrahl:
Do you really need the call to `tsc`? Seems to me the `tsc:w` watch task does a compile immediately - I see the same error, but the server starts up.

``` json
"start": "concurrently \"npm run tsc:w\" \"npm run lite\" ",
```
. Thanks Ward,

No need to reply, but here is the way I think about this:

Yeah I hear 'ya about the race condition, but it still seems better that the server starts up with errors, rather than not starting at all - the compiler will catch up after all. The big issue is that it's not super obvious that it's a script compilation error that's holding up the server from running. 

What I would expect here is that the server _always_ starts. if there is an error that error will show up either on the page (with console errors) or on the command line, but at that point I can fix and then see the change immediately. This is especially frustrating if you've had it work before assuming the server would always be there, and then fail another time because an error was introduced 'offline'. Then it's easy to miss the compile error and wonder why no server is loading :-)

Thanks. I can make this change myself, now that I know and hopefully there will be options on the TS compiler that let you control the result code returned.

No need to reply, but here is the way I think about this:

Yeah I hear 'ya about the race condition, but it still seems better that the server starts up with errors, rather than not starting at all - the compiler will catch up after all. The big issue is that it's not super obvious that it's a script compilation error that's holding up the server from running. 

What I would expect here is that the server _always_ starts. if there is an error that error will show up either on the page (with console errors) or on the command line, but at that point I can fix and then see the change immediately. This is especially frustrating if you've had it work before assuming the server would always be there, and then fail another time because an error was introduced 'offline'. Then it's easy to miss the compile error and wonder why no server is loading :-)

Thanks. I can make this change myself, now that I know and hopefully there will be options on the TS compiler that let you control the result code returned.
.

@AliMD 10.10.34.36:443 is a private range IP, which means it's filtered/censored in your area (the whole raw.githubusercontent.com). . I've attached my `gulpfile.js` file for those who are looking for a simple solution to start. Its `devDependencies` are mentioned in the `package.json` file. [BundlingRCfiles.zip](https://github.com/angular/quickstart/files/254559/BundlingRCfiles.zip) . @adamwuyu `Cannot find name 'Promise'` means you should add this line at the top of the main.ts file: ``` javascript /// ``` . after bundling, your index.html file, should look like this: ``` html My Application
Loading App...
``` Now `js/bundle.js` contains all the angular2 related files + your application's files (all of them). So you don't need to add `systemjs.config.js` entry anymore. because it's complied to a single file, using `systemjs-builder` task. Also `js/shims.js` now bundles `es6-shim.js & zone.js & Reflect.js` files. . @filipesilva `ng build -prod` doesn't embedded all of the application's .js files in the final `main.js` file. But the above gulp tasks, create a single `js/bundle.js` file which contains all of the angular2 related files + application's files (all of them). benefits : - single file deployment. - less round trips to the server - you can invalidate the cache of the browsers very easily, just by adding a simple query string at the end of the path (?v=1.x). But with deploying all of the .js files, cache invalidation won't happen easily. . A better solution: [Introduction to Webpack](https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/guide/webpack.html) It's also able to embed all of the .html and .css files too, using the **require** method: ``` typescript import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import '../../public/css/styles.css'; @Component({ selector: 'my-app', template: require('./app.component.html'), styles: [require('./app.component.css')] }) export class AppComponent { } ``` . It seems this method should not be used with angular2. [more info here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/33635528/298573) . If you want to mix typed and untyped coding styles, use ``` json "noImplicitAny": false, ``` in your `tsconfig.json` file. . You should not reference to `node_modules` folders directly. Use [webpack](https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/guide/webpack.html) to deploy the app. . `10.10.34.36:443` means https://raw.githubusercontent.com is filtered/censored in your country. But there's a better way to manage it these days. The new recommendation according to TS is to use NPM to manage your Typings: ``` npm install --save-dev @types/core-js ``` It's the same as installing a normal npm package, but it has @types/ at the beginning. [Solution](https://github.com/angular/quickstart/issues/63#issuecomment-235661066) by @j5concur worked for me
. Another way to fix it is to change `target` to `es6` in your `tsconfig.json`:

```
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "es6",
        "module": "commonjs",
        "moduleResolution": "node",
        "sourceMap": true,
        "emitDecoratorMetadata": true,
        "experimentalDecorators": true,
        "removeComments": false,
        "noImplicitAny": false
    }
}
```

layton-glympse:
# Don't change your target to ES6!!

@bedrin I don't mean this to be condescending or rude, but do you understand what changing your target to ES6 means? Am I the only person who thinks that is a bad solution? Having a target of ES6 means that the Typescript compiler is going to compile your Typescript code not to ECMAScript 5, but ECMAScript 6. ES6 is _quite far from being fully supported_. [See the Kangax ES6 compatibility tables](http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/) if you  are uncertain of this. If your project is going live on the internet, and it likely is, you _probably_ want users with the non-latest browsers (IE11, 10, 9, many phone browsers) to still be able to use your product. Safari doesn't even support a single part of the fat arrow function syntax, for instance.

Why does it fix the error, then? The reason setting your target to ES6 works is because ES6 natively supports promises.

### For anyone else who is coming here and thinks that targeting ES6 is a mistake here's the deal:

As of the time of this writing we should be using Typescript 2.0+. There's really no good reason not to with angular in final release status. The NG2 quickstart now provides TS2.0+ as a default starter version in their package.json, and the Typescript team is focused on it 

There are a few typings definitions needed for Angular. The new recommendation according to TS is to use NPM to manage your Typings, and we can finally ditch this huge confusing headache that was Typings definitions/config files. Angular 2 uses core-js, so we need to use:

`npm install --save-dev @types/core-js`

Many of your other `cannot find name [some-symbol]` errors will/should now be solved by simply installing your typings via NPM to your package.json. I don't even have a typings.config file anymore.

Sounds too good to be true, doesn't it? Well it's not. It's the future, and we're already in it. Sweet.

[Read more here](http://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/declaration-files/consumption.html) on the TS 2.0 way to consume typings.

P.S. I do still think that _finding_ typings definitions is the biggest pain, since there is usually no good correlation between a "missing name" and what typings definition actually provides support for that, but that's a different (and very frustrating) topic.

marcsyp:
For anyone arriving here looking for solutions to a similar problem, I was having the same problem with Ionic RC2-RC4, tried all kinds of things to fix it, including using npm to install typings, avoiding adding es6 as a target, etc... the thing that finally fixed it: updating the VS Code editor.  I had been postponing the updates for weeks, and for some reason, updating fixed it.  So go ahead and make sure your IDE is updated before you chase down all kinds of other solutions...

Marc. For anyone arriving here looking for solutions to a similar problem, I was having the same problem with Ionic RC2-RC4, tried all kinds of things to fix it, including using npm to install typings, avoiding adding es6 as a target, etc... the thing that finally fixed it: updating the VS Code editor.  I had been postponing the updates for weeks, and for some reason, updating fixed it.  So go ahead and make sure your IDE is updated before you chase down all kinds of other solutions...

Marc.

yavin5:
One more thing to try: Add this to the top of your ts file that needs Promises, Maps, etc:

`///<reference types="typescript/lib/lib.es6"/>`

If you use this instead of `///<reference path="../../node_modules/whatever"/>` then when you publish your code as a module, the reference still works!  This was very difficult and time consuming to figure out, and it appears to be magic.. One more thing to try: Add this to the top of your ts file that needs Promises, Maps, etc:

`///<reference types="typescript/lib/lib.es6"/>`

If you use this instead of `///<reference path="../../node_modules/whatever"/>` then when you publish your code as a module, the reference still works!  This was very difficult and time consuming to figure out, and it appears to be magic..

Sounds strange, thank you for reply, maybe I need a deep investigation~
. Hello,  after a quick search, this issue may due to I used the `sudo`, here are 2 kind of solutions
1.Run npm install with the --unsafe-perm flag:

``` bash
[sudo] npm install --unsafe-perm
```

2.Add the unsafe-perm flag to your `package.json`:

``` javascript
"config": {
    "unsafe-perm":true
}
```

But use `unsafe-perm` may have risk one guy mentioned.

1.Run npm install with the --unsafe-perm flag:

``` bash

```

2.Add the unsafe-perm flag to your `package.json`:

``` javascript
"config": {
    "unsafe-perm":true
}
```

But use `unsafe-perm` may have risk one guy mentioned.

mmiszy:
> It presupposes the existence of a `package.json` with systemjs config

No, it makes SystemJS respect `"main"` setting in package.json files and most npm packages have this one (including `@angular/*`). You still can (and should) add `packages:{…}` to your systemjs.config.js for packages which don't have `"main"` in their package.json but definitely it makes life easier for _most_ of the packages.
. > It presupposes the existence of a `package.json` with systemjs config

No, it makes SystemJS respect `"main"` setting in package.json files and most npm packages have this one (including `@angular/*`). You still can (and should) add `packages:{…}` to your systemjs.config.js for packages which don't have `"main"` in their package.json but definitely it makes life easier for _most_ of the packages.
.

J-Siu:
I am trying to learn Angular 2 and start following quickstart a few days ago. I ran into the exact same issue as stefanstelzer. Using 2.0.0-RC1 instead of master solved the issue.

The line that make the difference is in package.json, "typings": "^0.8.1" (2.0.0-RC1), instead of "^1.0.4" (master).

kylecordes:
Thanks. Yes, I know this mirrors the quickstart from angular.io. I'll close the issue, my goal was just to have one of the quickstart contributors glance and assess it... which you just did.
. That is an interesting opinion expressed by the writer there, but I don't agree with their interpretation of that section of the TypeScript documentation. In fact, the setting appears to work quite well for its intended purpose, and of course the ability to produce a SystemJS bundle is also noted in the TypeScript documentation.  It will take ordinary typescript modules in files as input, and it can produce either a separate file for each module of output, or it can produce a bundle. This demonstrably works, shown in my tiny commit above, and is in use on substantial projects "in the wild".  The sentence references, at the end of the following page, is incorrect.

https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript-Handbook/blob/master/pages/Namespaces%20and%20Modules.md

Of course this is all irrelevant to the actual issue here, which is whether there is merit in using this setting in the quickstart, and I think the answer to that is universally no.

anik786:
I though so to, but this is not required if you run typings like so:

`npm run postinstall`

or

`npm run typings install`

or if you have typings installed globally execute:

`typings install`

Thus many of the "Duplicate Identifier errors" go away! 

Not too sure why though as am still a bit confused what typings actually is.
. I had issues when running typescript, when "node_modules" was not in the excludes of "tsconfig.json". However when I installed the typings, all the errors went away. Not sure why. 

But you may still be right in that "node_modules" should still be there.
. Try the following:

```
rm -r node_modules
rm -r typings
npm install
npm run postinstall
npm start
```
. I personally had problems with the "lite-server" myself. 

Consider using a proper server like Apache or PHP's built in server like so (assuming you have PHP installed):

```
php -S localhost:8080
```
. if Timz solution did not work try running each node command separately to identify what is giving you problems like so:

`npm run tsc`
`npm run tsc -w`
`npm run lite-server`

Which ones work?

```
rm -r node_modules
rm -r typings
npm install
npm run postinstall
npm start
```

Yep I did the npm install...think I discovered what it was though I think it is still an issue going forwards.

So I had an export class like this one below - it seems important that npm start is running whilst you write out this code then it will compile and any issues will get reported as a failed build error message in the browser or a console error in the browser

If for some reason the npm start needs to be stopped or in my case you finish for the day and try to restart npm start the next day then it will fail to launch the server.

The below code does have a legitimate error the users; variable should really be users: any[];

But this error does not really justify the difference in the way the build runs

```
export class HomeComponent implements OnInit {
    errorMessage: string;
    users;

    constructor (private usersService: UsersService){}

    ngOnInit() { this.getUsers(); }

    getUsers(){
        this.usersService.getUsers()
            .subscribe(
                data => this.users.push(data),
                error => this.errorMessage = <any>error
            )
    }

}
```

technoloG:
I was under the impression that the Quickstart was for developing Angular 2 projects in Visual Studio 2015. If I am mistaken, please advise.

That being said, as of Step 3 in the QuickStart documentation, it is suggested to open a new ASP.NET project in Visual Studio. While suggested workflow works for ASP.NET 4.x projects, things have changed in ASP.NET 5 - better known as ASP.NET Core - projects. The impression left wasn't one with a focus on ASP.NET development, but more of a workflow with said projects.

As of recent updates to Visual Studio 2015 and the introduction of ASP.NET Core, the project structure has changed slightly, including explicitly having `wwwroot` in the root of the project - where static files are intended to reside and be viewed in the browser. As a result, the steps provided in the QuickStart for Visual Studio 2015 don't necessarily apply.

The assumption was that the QuickStart was intended to help get things up and running quickly in Visual Studio. Doing a full deploy - using Webpack or otherwise - seems like overkill at that point. However, as it stands, some additional consideration for the latest project workflow in Visual Studio would be helpful.
. I'm referring to the Visual Studio 2015 QuickStart documentation, under the Cookbook section:
https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/cookbook/visual-studio-2015.html
. Done. See here: https://github.com/angular/angular.io/issues/1752

Thanks for the guidance.

diegotham:
You can use a volume, for example with a docker-compose.yml like this:

```
 version: '2'
 services:
   angular:
     build: .
     ports:
      - 80:3000
     volumes:
      - ./app:/quickstart/app
```
. I signed it!

nan140114:
Hi @andy-dev ! i had the same problem, this works for me:

**Dockerfile:**

```
FROM node:latest
WORKDIR /quickstart
COPY package.json /quickstart/
RUN npm install --unsafe-perm=true
CMD npm start
```
1. delete the `.dockerignore` file, or delete the line `node_modules/` in the  `.dockerignore` file.
2. build the image, for example `docker build -t angular2  .`
3. run the container with `docker run -it --rm  -v **host_path**:/quickstart -p 3000:3000 -p 3001:3001 angular2
   `

now, when you modify  the project files, the project is 'compiled' again, and the browser is refreshed.
. Hi @andy-dev ! i had the same problem, this works for me:

**Dockerfile:**

```
FROM node:latest
WORKDIR /quickstart
COPY package.json /quickstart/
RUN npm install --unsafe-perm=true
CMD npm start
```
1. delete the `.dockerignore` file, or delete the line `node_modules/` in the  `.dockerignore` file.
2. build the image, for example `docker build -t angular2  .`
3. run the container with `docker run -it --rm  -v **host_path**:/quickstart -p 3000:3000 -p 3001:3001 angular2
   `

now, when you modify  the project files, the project is 'compiled' again, and the browser is refreshed.

I'm confused by what configuration fields mean, and what they affect. - Related config information must be specified in multiple places, but I'm unclear on the differences - What does /base/ (in karma.conf.js) mean? - Many symbol names collide, making it difficult to understand scope and usage. ### Details Trying to configure karma and systemjs has been very difficult. I would appreciate any references you could provide me. **karma** I can't say I understand how karma works yet, and there doesn't seem to be much of a tutorial. All I've found is: http://karma-runner.github.io/1.0/intro/how-it-works.html, which is surprisingly terse. It refers to a masters thesis, which I haven't read yet, but I'm looking for something in between, and which is specific to karma. The karma configuration seems to be much more complex than what is described in http://karma-runner.github.io/1.0/config/configuration-file.html and http://karma-runner.github.io/1.0/config/files.html. **systemjs** I feel I have a better understanding of the system.js loader. I found the documentation on the https://github.com/systemjs/systemjs to be easier to understand, but it is still a complex component that will take me some fair time and work to understand. **karma and system.js together with angular** In particular, I'd like to understand the details of how browser URLs are sent to the karma server, and how they are resolved. I don't understand what resolution is performed in the browser, and what is performed by the karma server, which paths are relative, and which are from the root. The documentation seems to assume that the reader already understands these things. I also don't understand what the special prefix **/base/** refers, and I can't find documentation that discusses this. Another point of confusion is that the same symbol names are used for many things. I think that using a separate symbols for each concept would help greatly. In particular, **app** has many uses, and I believe many people in the community assume that it's use is required, for example this [question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38886456/how-do-i-configure-the-code-directories-in-karma-for-angular2). I'm used to web-apps not knowing the file system structure of the server, but it seems like many portions of the URLs are expected to match. **changing the project directory structure** I have several components in one project. You can find my first attempt in the [browser-angular2 component of people-service](https://github.com/psnider/people-service/tree/master/components/browser-angular2). This was basically working, but broke when zone.js upgraded, see [issue](https://github.com/angular/quickstart/issues/186). Then as I started to work through this, the tutorial was updated to RC5, so I'm redoing the work to incorporate it. . @filipesilva @wardbell Thanks so much! For now, my all-TypeScript micro-service project, https://github.com/psnider/people-service, is almost complete! I'm trying to use best practices for everything, especially testing. bjornharvold:
+1 I looked at Angular CLI as well but I'd like to see this project come up with a solve. Right now, the development part of this project uses lite-server and hot reload is 3 times faster than the Angular CLI setup right now. I also don't like Angular CLI's way of having to build per environment. There is a great article: http://www.jvandemo.com/how-to-configure-your-angularjs-application-using-environment-variables/ about externalizing the environment file from the build. The deployment phase can be responsible for providing the app with the correct environment variables. "Build once - Deploy anywhere".

Cheers!

theBull:
My guess is that this recommendation is more obvious within the context of a larger application and development environment. Running the app and tests simultaneously could cause one or more of the processes to run inefficiently and take longer, especially within an org with many unit and **especially e2e tests**. If the application runs slowly because you've got a lot of memory allocated to your tests, it could falsely convey that the application itself has a performance issue.

Just my two cents, I could be way off.

**\- Edited to reflect emphasis on e2e test performance impacts.**

. Yes, this issue was created with SystemJS and Karma.

I figured it out, it's actually is a silly bug. The error reported is a socket error, Karma tries to run on the defined port and on failure we have something like:

`Chrome 52.0.2743 (Linux 0.0.0): Executed 0 of 3 SUCCESS (0 secs / 0 secs)`
`Missing error handler on socket.`

This can be easily reproduced if you start `npm run test`, stop/pause the process and attempts to run it again.

I saw somewhere else a Karma config that auto increments the port until it picks a free port.
. I _guess_ that since you are using a baseURL, you need to map your local file to that path.

Those test folders are just warnings.

`Chrome 52.0.2743 (Linux 0.0.0): Executed 0 of 3 SUCCESS (0 secs / 0 secs)`
`Missing error handler on socket.`

This can be easily reproduced if you start `npm run test`, stop/pause the process and attempts to run it again.

I saw somewhere else a Karma config that auto increments the port until it picks a free port.
. I _guess_ that since you are using a baseURL, you need to map your local file to that path.

Those test folders are just warnings. 
.

. Okay found a solution here:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34399445/angular-2-quickstart-live-server-error

In brief:

Change the Package.json Scripts Settings
"start": "tsc && concurrently \"npm run tsc:w\" \"npm run lite\",
to
"start": "concurrently \"npm run tsc:w\" \"npm run lite\" ",

```

Dickurt:
@olivierto I had the same issue. Try adding this to your Dockerfile

```
RUN npm install -g tsc \
    && npm install -g concurrently \
    && npm install -g typescript \
```

For me, that only solved part of the issue. For some reason, `npm install` did not save the dependencies after installing them. So I had to manually run `npm install` in the docker container, i.e. `docker run angular npm install` and then `docker run angular npm run typings install`.

This is only a workaround, of course. But at least it gets things going. I have yet to find a solution.

Hope that helps!

core2duo:
@egeogretmen hey, I have the same issue and I have a solution for that. But (and it's more important) I have a reason of this issue.
I'm using vagrant with Debian 8 on my Win10 laptop and I have a shared folder with my project.
I had to use 'npm install' with '--no-bin-links' option because it's not possible to place a symlink in a shared folder. So, my node_modules/.bin/ directory is empty. And that's the reason of the problem.
Try 'npm bin' and see is your bin directory empty or not.
The solution is quite simple, you just have to change 'scripts' in packages.json to use local versions of the packages like that:

``` javascript
"scripts": {
  "start": "node ./node_modules/concurrently/src/main.js \"npm run tsc:w\" \"npm run lite\" ",
  "lite": "./node_modules/lite-server/bin/lite-server",
  "tsc": "./node_modules/typescript/bin/tsc",
  "tsc:w": "./node_modules/typescript/bin/tsc -w"
}
```

ibqn:
I have created one for myself, based on the AOT tutorial: [aot-quick-start](https://github.com/ibqn/ng2-quick-start). The typescript version 1.8 used above might be simply too old, please try with 2.0.10

I am personally not aware of the VS integration, but the way I run it on windows is:

- install [git bash](https://git-for-windows.github.io/)
- install [nodejs](https://nodejs.org/en/download/)
- open git bash window and clone the repo (git clone https://github.com/angular/quickstart.git)
- run 'cd quickstart' followed by 'npm install' and 'npm start'
. @Foxandxss where do you have this information from, any reference? Last time I have tried, it worked perfectly on Windows 10, with [Git bash](https://git-for-windows.github.io/). @wardbell Your sentence in README is sadly quite contra-productive and confusing, please provide a reference and what is exactly meant by _Bash for Windows_ as there are multiple ways to get bash prompt in windows. . @Foxandxss I strongly disagree here, there is nothing I can see from the reference which you have provided literally called "Bash for Windows".  The thing you are referring to is called "Windows subsystem for Linux" which is quite new and still considered as a beta technology! This beta feature is based on ubuntu and that is why for short sometimes one can see references to bash prompt as "bash on ubuntu on windows".

There are multiple ways to have a working bash environment on windows which exist since decades.

That is why wording like "Bash for Windows" is not unique and thus very confusing, unless it is clearly stated which technology is used to provide bash. . fadc80:
I have solved this issue appending system-polyfills.js to karma.conf.js:

```
files: [
  // System.js for module loading
  'node_modules/systemjs/dist/system.src.js',
  'node_modules/systemjs/dist/system-polyfills.js',
```

Why it is not needed for Chrome?

SO Refererence: [How to configure Angular 2 Quickstart to run phantomjs?](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/40470806/how-to-configure-angular2-quickstart-to-run-phantomjs)
. I have solved this issue appending system-polyfills.js to karma.conf.js:

Adding this:

````
/// <reference path="../node_modules/@types/node/index.d.ts" />
````

to the top of my app module fixes my issue, but this is old typescript syntax I feel like I really shouldn't be using.  There should be a `tsconfig.json` way to resolve this, but the "exclude" setting seems to override most of my options there.. Hm, I'll keep pokin at it then.  I actually started the angular quickstart tutorial last week and then it was updated halfway through, so I'm kind of straddling worlds here.  I updated the various json and config files and I feel like I've got everything up to date, but this is really the first weird issue I'm finding.

A couple things I am doing differently, though:

- I'm using atom-typescript to compile instead of the tsc command-line watch, the IDE assistance is invaluable and I think I was double-building everything before, so I just run lite-server and let atom do what it does
- I've set a custom "outDir" since building all the js and map files in my working app directory was proving to be an indecipherable mess (this is something I'd like to see changed in this repo actually).  Though this isn't ideal, since my template files aren't automatically moved from `app` to `dist` like my typescript output is.  I'll need a more robust build process here in the future, to be sure.

When I try to run tsc on the command line, I actually get a whole separate set of errors, like thirty separate errors in `node_modules/@types/core-js/index.d.ts` complaining mainly about modifiers.  So there may indeed be something weird with my setup that I don't entirely understand.

styleUrls: ['app.component.css'],

lars-erik:
Seems related to this: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/41232228/running-npm-start-fails-due-to-error
I just had the same happen in a project, and explicitly using "@types/selenium-webdriver": "2.53.33" made it work.
. I'd make a PR, but I'm sure it'll be really quick for anyone who already have a fork. :)
The solution is to add a leading `/` to the `appAssets` variable in karma.conf.js.

    var appAssets = '/base/app/';

Ref.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/41243183/karma-fails-to-proxy-html-with-the-angular-2-quickstart-config
and
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/32434792/karma-proxies-are-not-working. \o/. Seems related to this: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/41232228/running-npm-start-fails-due-to-error
I just had the same happen in a project, and explicitly using "@types/selenium-webdriver": "2.53.33" made it work.
. I'd make a PR, but I'm sure it'll be really quick for anyone who already have a fork. :)
The solution is to add a leading `/` to the `appAssets` variable in karma.conf.js.

    var appAssets = '/base/app/';

Ref.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/41243183/karma-fails-to-proxy-html-with-the-angular-2-quickstart-config
and
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/32434792/karma-proxies-are-not-working. \o/.

alfian777:
Hi i run to similar issue with you. 

While i'm not sure how to properly fix this issue but let me share my workaround.

First.
You may want to update your SHELL env var by pointing it to your git bash location.
` export SHELL="/c/Program Files/Git/bin/bash" `
change the path to where your git bash location.

If up until this point you succeed then no need to change anything else. If not (I'm not). Then there is a problem in path resolve process. when you look deep inside **spawn-default-shell/src/get-shell.js** Node Modules they are trying to compare our SHELL path with common shell regex.
`const DETECT_SH_REGEX = /sh$/;`
that variable assume that all shell name must end with "sh" while in our case it turns out to be 
`C:\Program Files\Git\bin\bash.exe`
which means ends with "sh.exe" then it trows an error. 

so the solution is change 
`const DETECT_SH_REGEX = /sh$/;`
to 
`const DETECT_SH_REGEX = /sh/;`

Hope that helps, pardon me if i wrongly explain something.

For more detailed explanation or complete solution please look here:
[github.com/kimmobrunfeldt/spawn-default-shell/issues/6](https://github.com/kimmobrunfeldt/spawn-default-shell/issues/6)

Note : Since this solution change one node modules which is outside our project, be sure to change this again once you "nuke" your node modules folder, OR submit a pull request to the cause of the problem.. Hi i run to similar issue with you.

`const DETECT_SH_REGEX = /sh$/;`
that variable assume that all shell name must end with "sh" while in our case it turns out to be 
`C:\Program Files\Git\bin\bash.exe`
which means ends with "sh.exe" then it trows an error. 

so the solution is change 
`const DETECT_SH_REGEX = /sh$/;`
to 
`const DETECT_SH_REGEX = /sh/;`

Hope that helps, pardon me if i wrongly explain something.

For more detailed explanation or complete solution please look here:
[github.com/kimmobrunfeldt/spawn-default-shell/issues/6](https://github.com/kimmobrunfeldt/spawn-default-shell/issues/6)

Note : Since this solution change one node modules which is outside our project, be sure to change this again once you "nuke" your node modules folder, OR submit a pull request to the cause of the problem..

Update : 10h37 20 Jan : doing another fresh git clone and running the `clone` , `install` , `e2e`  I am now no longer able to reproduce the error. I had observed the error for a few days on various other fresh checkouts, and for the life of me I can't see what's changed on my system if anything.  Closing this issue as I'm satisfied its most likely a really odd local machine issue. (from my noobie perspective) . **I think I've worked out the sequence of how I ended up with the symptoms described** 

- I was initially running the `npm run test` (unit test) and this was working ok. 
- I was following along  a play-by-play with @jonpapa and I believe I had done a few of steps before actually running e2e for the first time. 
- That test runs, and there's no visible error in the Chrome window that appears, however, if the title of the `Hello Angular` changes to something that the end to end spec does not expect the test fails, but the chrome window does not show anything similar to the error you see in a failed unit test
 - also, the output in the console window is quite long, and the text showing `1 failed spec(s)` had already scrolled off the window, and the only visible text is the `npm ERR! texts` with a very specific messaging encouraging the submission of an `angular-quickstart` bug report.
- I'm a noobie angular (and javascript) developer, and come from an ops-ish background, `fake, msbuild` etc, where I'm used to making sure the build outputs are as simple as possible, and can read like a story. 

**lesson learnt?**

- **Returning (1) to npm, plus we should be able to also return friendly error message**
- test on multiple machines?
- test with with colleague first, before submitting bug report
- protractor/jasmine (?) output should not show `npm ERR!` output from a test run, imho.
- ERR! should only ever be shown to indicate an unexpected script error, with the script itself, not with what the script is doing. If I see `ERR!` then should immediately be able to reason (with high confidence) that something in the build process is broken, not the latest code change. 
- It should be easy for a non programmer to read the build output and the error message should be self documenting. There is possibly scope for improvement in the build process that comes with the `quickstart` templates.
- the test failing, was actually valid, and was not a script error. The test executed successfully and returned a valid error result of (1). 
- possibly a discussion around how noisy should an 'npm' error be, and under what circumstances can we override the npm default error messages?
- If there is a way to return (1) to 'npm' as well as the appropriate error message to display, one for (verbose) and other for (standard) then that would be possibly be easy to configure?
- build code is mixed in tightly with `src` code in the quickstart. Possibly needs some simple separation.. Ah great, thanks for the feedback. Does this mean you'll update the quickstart?  (Sorry too new to npm and javascript to dive in and submit a pull request myself.) Plus signing the contracts to `become a contributor` seems overboard for a 1 liner fix? ;-D. Neron-Liu:
Hi guys, 

I also went into this issue today, and it finally got fixed by steps:
1. change "rxjs" version in package.json from "5.0.1" to "5.0.2"
2. change "typescript" version in package.json to "~2.2.1"
3. remove node_modules, and then do "npm install" again

My versions are:
node - 6.10.0
npm  - 3.10.10

leebenson:
I've submitted a [PR](https://github.com/angular/angular.io/pull/3160)

Workaround:

> cat non-essential-files.txt | xargs rm -rf. you could also do:

`rm -rf $(cat non-essential-files.txt)`

... which, AFAIK, expands the same way all *nix systems.

Of course, always be sure you know exactly what you're executing when it comes to `rm -rf`... if '/' happens to be in the file for some odd reason, and you're a sudo user, you could wipe out your entire system in one go!. good catch @trescenzi 

Although, to be clear, `-a` is not a valid xargs switch on OS X (at least Sierra). So even if the encoding is fixed, it'll still fail.

`rm -rf $(cat non-essential-files.txt)` works as-is on my Mac, even with the current format.

So I'd suggest either:

1. Fixing the file, and making `rm -rf $(cat non-essential-files.txt)` the official *nix blurb
2. Having separate instructions for OS X / other *nix flavours where `xargs -a` is valid. I encountered pretty much everything @magnayn discovered in my first few days of using Angular, and wound up writing my own Webpack config.

It was a giant PITA that took:

-  3 different TypeScript loaders to find one that actually works (hint: `awesome-typescript-loader`)
-  Trawling through SO and issue boards to figure to figure out why I was getting cyclic dependency issues in the build (hint: `/angular(\\|\/)core(\\|\/)(esm(\\|\/)src|src)(\\|\/)linker/` - yeah, WTF)
-  Separate loaders for routine stuff like `templateUrl` to resolve _actual_ files, and not just throw cryptic console 404s
- Proper handling of HTML and CSS processing/minification (including postcss)
- Walking the tightrope that is `tsconfig.json` to appease both TypeScript and webpack and actually get it to _build something_ that works.
- Swapping out the 90% of starter kits that use Webpack 1, and miss out on tree-shaking of v2 and es6 modules
- Separate builders for universal Angular, so initial page dumps/SSR were possible
- Proper hot reloading -- not full refreshes like with browsersync

I'm a new ng user transitioning from React, so luckily I had some experience with wrestling webpack. For someone that's completely new to this, I have no idea how anyone has actually managed to deploy working ng2 code any further than their laptop. Kudos to anyone navigating this learning curve. I spent 5 mins on the official docs before submitting a PR for a pretty obvious error. It's a minefield, and seemingly an exercise that (for now out least) is left to the developer.

I'm still working on it, but I'm gonna finish my webpack config and post it as an alternative to the starter kits currently out there. Hopefully it helps save someone else 3 days of their life trying to get 'hello world' to compile.

The CLI is a great effort, but hiding the set-up behind magic is going to bite people in the ass before too long. Anyone coming from a 'magic' framework like Meteor will know exactly what I'm talking about.. And, I'm sure I speak for others @Foxandxss, I certainly appreciate all efforts to build something like this quickstart guide. My main peev as a new user is lack of 'official' consistency. A user is either faced with going it alone or trusting everything to the CLI. Neither is ideal.

A simple, solid webpack starter that works in browsers and generates first-page HTML - and is **kept up to date** - would be awesome.

I'll post my attempt at that here when it's finished, hopefully in the next couple of days.. I've submitted a [PR](https://github.com/angular/angular.io/pull/3160)

000000b0  0a                                                |.|
000000b1
```

The solution should be as simple as copying the file to your clipboard and then pasting it over the existing file. That worked for me.

Here's also a list without the offending characters you can paste into a file that will work with `xargs -a <file> rm -rf`

```
.git
.gitignore
.travis.yml
*.spec*.ts
CHANGELOG.md
e2e
favicon.ico
karma.conf.js
karma-test-shim.js
LICENSE
non-essential-files.txt
protractor.config.js
README.md
```

For those uncertain if it's working try `xargs -a <file> ls` and it'll show you what will be touched by the command.. @leebenson I think `1.` makes the most sense. Sounds like you'd have to fix the file regardless and it's probably better to use a command that's valid on more *nix flavors(including OS X).

Meligy:
My understanding is that this project serves as a local equivalent of the online demo that's available in the Angular docs. It's meant to be as close as possible to the online thing, without the overhead of actually loading all packages from remote sources etc. 

The disclaimer about it being non optimal for production has been for a while. It just needed an answer to the next logical question "If this isn't good for production, what is?", which this PR addresses.. jmetev1: Tour of heroes seems aimed at very new people. The repo is originally setup to compile from src and output compiled .js files back to src. People new to angular or new to the concept of having separate source .ts files and compiled .js files are likely to get confused. I thought it would be better to separate them.. There are ways to deal with it if you're an advanced user. But if the quickstart is aimed at people very new to angular and new to having separate compiled files, it would be nice if the compiled files weren't mixed in with the .ts files that have almost the same name and are superficially similar in content.. No it doesn't. It seems the angular quickstart example is a 'little' behind the current state.. @mrdjar ... I also got your error. It simply means `typescript` isn't installed (`tsc` is typescript). So if you do `npm install typescript -g ` that should already fix your error.

But then you will get others. In the current state the rxjs version in use by the tutorial won't work (because of an error in the "lift" function), if you change in `package.json` rxjs and typescript to "rxjs": "^5.4.2" and "typescript": "^2.3.4" and do `npm install` again, then that part should also work.

But then you get some other errors, which  I'm not yet through yet.. No it doesn't. It seems the angular quickstart example is a 'little' behind the current state.. @mrdjar ... I also got your error.
